content.title: Atrial Fibrillation Rhythm Control
content.summary: Strategies to restore and maintain sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation
key_points: Rhythm control preferred in symptomatic patients
Cardioversion (electrical or pharmacologic) restores sinus rhythm
Catheter ablation (PVI) is first-line for paroxysmal AF
Antiarrhythmic drugs maintain sinus rhythm post-cardioversion
Drug choice depends on structural heart disease presence
Anticoagulation still needed even after successful rhythm control

statement.text: Rhythm control in AF aims to restore and maintain sinus rhythm through cardioversion (electrical or pharmacologic), antiarrhythmic drugs, and/or catheter ablation. Pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) is now first-line for symptomatic paroxysmal AF. Rhythm control may improve outcomes when initiated early (EAST-AFNET 4 trial).
statement.formal: AF Rhythm Control = Cardioversion → [AAD maintenance OR Catheter ablation (PVI)] → Continue anticoagulation

explanation.intuition: Rhythm control tries to eliminate AF and restore the normal heartbeat. This involves zapping the heart back to normal rhythm (cardioversion), then using drugs or ablation to keep it there. The goal is symptom relief and potentially better long-term outcomes.
explanation.key_insight: EAST-AFNET 4 showed early rhythm control (within 1 year of diagnosis) reduces cardiovascular events compared to rate control. This has shifted thinking toward more aggressive early rhythm management, especially with safer ablation techniques.

definitions_glossary.rhythm_control: Strategy to restore and maintain sinus rhythm in AF
definitions_glossary.cardioversion: Restoration of sinus rhythm by electrical shock or drugs
definitions_glossary.DC_cardioversion: Synchronized electrical shock to reset heart rhythm
definitions_glossary.pharmacologic_cardioversion: Drug-induced restoration of sinus rhythm (flecainide, propafenone, ibutilide)
definitions_glossary.catheter_ablation: Invasive procedure creating lesions to eliminate AF substrate
definitions_glossary.pulmonary_vein_isolation: Ablation electrically isolating pulmonary veins from left atrium
definitions_glossary.antiarrhythmic_drug: Medication preventing AF recurrence after cardioversion
definitions_glossary.TEE_guided_cardioversion: Using transesophageal echo to rule out LAA thrombus before cardioversion
definitions_glossary.pill_in_pocket: Self-administered flecainide/propafenone for infrequent paroxysmal AF
definitions_glossary.ablation_substrate: Structural and electrical abnormalities maintaining AF
definitions_glossary.cryoablation: Ablation using cold (freezing) energy vs radiofrequency (heat)

pathophysiology.AF_initiation: Triggers from pulmonary veins initiate AF
pathophysiology.AF_maintenance: Atrial remodeling creates substrate for reentry and perpetuation
pathophysiology.ablation_rationale: PVI eliminates triggers; substrate modification addresses maintenance

electrical.anticoagulation: 3 weeks before + 4 weeks after (or TEE to exclude thrombus)

pharmacologic.flecainide: 200-300mg PO (Class IC); no structural heart disease
pharmacologic.propafenone: 450-600mg PO (Class IC); no structural heart disease
pharmacologic.ibutilide: 1mg IV over 10 min, repeat if needed (Class III); QT monitoring
pharmacologic.amiodarone: IV or PO loading; slower conversion but safe in structural HD

PVI.indication: First-line for symptomatic paroxysmal AF; reasonable for persistent

catheter_ablation.post_ablation: Continue anticoagulation 2-3 months minimum; long-term based on CHA2DS2-VASc

hybrid_approaches.ablation_plus_AAD: Combined approach may be more effective than either alone
hybrid_approaches.surgical_ablation: MAZE procedure during cardiac surgery; standalone thoracoscopic ablation

definition.@value: Strategies using cardioversion, antiarrhythmic drugs, and catheter ablation to restore and maintain sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation

learning_objectives: Select appropriate antiarrhythmic based on structural heart disease
Recognize when ablation is preferred over AADs
clinical_pearls: Class IC drugs (flecainide, propafenone) contraindicated in structural HD - proarrhythmic risk
Continue anticoagulation after ablation based on CHA2DS2-VASc, not rhythm
Early rhythm control (within 1 year) may reduce CV events (EAST-AFNET 4)
Pill-in-pocket only for infrequent, hemodynamically stable paroxysmal AF
Amiodarone is effective but has significant long-term toxicity

sources.source: EAST-AFNET 4 Trial. N Engl J Med 2020;383:1305-1316
